Lord of the Flies ğŸ¦Ÿ

Genre: Dystopian fiction, Allegory


â€œThe thing is â€“ fear canâ€™t hurt you any more than a dream.â€ğŸŒ¿



I read this book last year and I would say I found it to be quite a haunting book. It started out by presenting a group of boys and their attempt to survive at a deserted island, but the story took a dark twist once a power struggle developed between the characters. Golding associates the inclination of civilization with good and the instinct of savagery with evil throughout the book. The novel's central theme is the clash between the two instincts, which is addressed through the disintegration of the young English boys' civilised, moral, and disciplined behaviour as they adjust to a wild, cruel, and savage life in the island. 


#qotd: Have you read this book? I would like to know your thoughts on it ğŸğŸ“š


Description: 

William Golding's 1954 novel "Lord of the Flies" tells the story of a group of young boys who find themselves alone on a deserted island. They develop rules and a system of organisation, but without any adults to serve as a civilising impulse, the children eventually become violent and brutal.




#lordoftheflies #lordofthefliesbook #williamgolding #igreads #igreadsuk #bookstagram #bookish #dystopianfiction #allegorical #classic #conchshell #book #bookstagramuk #booklover #bookreviewer #bookreader #bookblog #bookblogger #bookcommunity

While decluttering over the weekend and trying to rearrange my room, I stumbled on this novel that was one of the many texts recommended for us back in secondary school. Art students can relate better ğŸ˜†

Taking it back to the old times, its title 'Lord of The Flies' attracted me to the book, hoping it would be one of those fables with animal narratives.

In my head, I had assumed its content only to be wowed by the storyline as it turned out to be a completely different genre.

The summary of my epistle is to never judge a book not only by its cover but also by its titleğŸ˜†

*There's always more to what we see on the outside!*
..

Because of this book I  was late for work a few times and I didn't care, I just wanted to finish the chapter and see what was gonna happen next. #lordoftheflies #bookworm #books #lordofthefliesbook #ineedmorebooks

ğŸ So begins the classical tale of survival on a deserted island, however, it isnâ€™t long before something far more sinister starts to occur.

Lord of the Flies was William Goldingâ€™s debut novel and was rejected eight times by publishers before finally being accepted. A simple childhood story on the surface, the novel holds a darker meaning at its core. It has been awarded numerous awards over the years as well as being listed in over a dozen â€œBest Booksâ€ lists.

Although some chose to read it as a somewhat nonsensical tale, others see a deeper significance. It deals with civilization versus savagery, the decaying of society, and the inherent evil within humankind.

January's Read ğŸ“–
Lord Of The Flies by William Golding
~
~
~
~
And my first book of 2021 is finished! 
Definitely started this year of strong with a good old classic and one that I have never read up until now. 

The book itself is beautifully narrated even with some of its grotesque imagery and scenes. However it did take me a lot longer to read than I originally thought. 
Not one of my favourite books to have read recently but it's one to definitely tick of the list to read!!!
~

well, this post isnt about another au being made so yeah-

[MINOR SPOILER WARNING FOR LORD OF THE FLIES!]

this was for a school project i had to do, i was given many prompts related to a section of chapters in Lord Of The Flies (7-10), and i chose to symbolize how Ralph slowly lost his title of being chief. i added a broken/worn down crown to symbolize how he lost his status as a ruler/leader, and the conch because it played a big part in assemblies to enforce rules, (and other stuff)
this was a bit different but i hope you liked it!

Lord of the Flies.
.
The boys and I just finished the classic novel.
.
And, wow!
.
We gleaned SO MUCH from author, William Golding in this book. The points he makes on society and government are so intelligent.
.
And the novel is extremely rich in symbolism and continues to parallel modern society, despite being published in 1954.
.
Have you read Lord of the Flies with your teenagers?
.
.
.

Now that it's the last day of July, it's time for reading updates ğŸ˜€

Now this is how I spent my July, reading wise -

- The Cousins by Karen M McManus
- The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides
- Fangirl by Rainbow Rowell
- The Maiden Bride by Rexanne Becnel (cannot find its picture for some reason)
- Born a Crime by Trevor Noah (haven't finished it yet)
- Lord of the Flies by William Golding
- In Pursuit of Happiness by Freya Kennedy (currently reading)
- Anxious People by Fredrik Backman (currently reading)

How many books did you read this July and what was your favorite and least favorite read?

ğ™ğ™ğ™šğ™® ğ™ªğ™£ğ™™ğ™šğ™§ğ™¨ğ™©ğ™¤ğ™¤ğ™™ ğ™¤ğ™£ğ™¡ğ™® ğ™©ğ™¤ğ™¤ ğ™¬ğ™šğ™¡ğ™¡ ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™¡ğ™ğ™—ğ™šğ™§ğ™–ğ™©ğ™ğ™¤ğ™£ ğ™ğ™£ğ™©ğ™¤ ğ™¨ğ™–ğ™«ğ™–ğ™œğ™šğ™§ğ™® ğ™©ğ™ğ™–ğ™© ğ™©ğ™ğ™š ğ™˜ğ™¤ğ™£ğ™˜ğ™šğ™–ğ™¡ğ™ğ™£ğ™œ ğ™¥ğ™–ğ™ğ™£ğ™© ğ™—ğ™§ğ™¤ğ™ªğ™œğ™ğ™©.
- ğ˜šğ˜ªğ˜³ ğ˜ğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜ªğ˜¢ğ˜® ğ˜ğ˜°ğ˜­ğ˜¥ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨.

Group of boys stranded on an uninhabited island with no adults in sight trying to be civilized, having rules, choosing a chief, making plans etc. A rudimentary democracy with happy and purposeful citizens.

Fearing something is so seductive. You cannot prove ghosts, you have never seen one but you're always afraid of one. Fear festers unchecked fueling rich traditions, birthing blind customs and murdering logic and sanity.

Some are logical leaders and some are colourful crowd-pleasers who say what most people want to hear.

Loyalty, courage and friendship.

When all rules go to hell, anarchy commences. Maybe "Sapiens" was right. Rules, laws and other societal constructs are really unreal myths, pieces of a fertile brain and the moment we stop believing in them, they stop existing. However we need them otherwise nothing will ever make sense for us to function properly.

Masks and paints. An age old way to conceal our realities and truth. Become a new person. Someone more beautiful, someone stronger, someone more formidable. Someone who isn't afraid. If we can lose ourselves in our false self then maybe we'll do those things that our true selves would shudder to even think.

I know it's a dystopian fiction but there are some things we can learn from it. When you next chose your leader, think if (s)he's just a crowd pleaser making tempting promises or if (s)he is vocal about issues that make sense and sets beneficial  goals.

â—â—â—
In other news, me and @b00ksah0lic have recorded a podcast on Lord Of The Flies discussing some plot details and why we loved the book. Be sure to check it out, Spotify link in bio. And spoiler alert if you haven't read the book yet.

"O Senhor das Moscas" Ã© um livro que eu quero ler hÃ¡ quase 20 anos, por conta de uma disciplina que tive que abandonar na Letras. Comecei a leitura bem afoita e conforme contei nos stories, a princÃ­pio a histÃ³ria nÃ£o me cativou, eu nÃ£o conseguia prever pra onde a histÃ³ria iria e por isso, talvez, tenha se dado um estranhamento. Conjecturas. Mas vamos ao enredo bÃ¡sico: um aviÃ£o cai numa ilha na Ã©poca da segunda guerra, com crianÃ§as de 6 a 13 anos como sobreviventes, nÃ£o tem nenhum adulto com eles. Num primeiro momento Ralph Ã© eleito o lÃ­der pelas crianÃ§as mas encontra oposiÃ§Ã£o em Jack, que quer caÃ§ar enquanto Ralph tem como preocupaÃ§Ã£o alimentar uma fogueira para um possÃ­vel resgate. Se no comeÃ§o as crianÃ§as estÃ£o fascinadas com a vida sem supervisÃ£o adulta e com o vislumbre da liberdade, eles vÃ£o aos poucos descobrindo que essa vida na ilha estÃ¡ mexendo com a cabeÃ§a deles - cada um a sua forma - e entÃ£o conflitos comeÃ§am a acontecer com frequÃªncia atÃ© a apariÃ§Ã£o do "Senhor das Moscas" que dÃ¡ tÃ­tulo ao livro. Esses conflitos terÃ£o consequÃªncias com a qual todos os garotos eventualmente, terÃ£o de lidar.
.
.
Se eu pudesse resumir "O Senhor das Moscas" numa palavra, seria: simbÃ³lico. A histÃ³ria Ã© muito rica de simbolismos: a ilha, no micro Ã© uma alegoria da sociedade, constantemente dividida entre a ordem e o caos. O homem que estaria inevitavelmente fadado Ã  violÃªncia e selvageria, o eterno embate entre o bem e o mal em cada um de nÃ³s. Acho simbÃ³lico tambÃ©m que a salvaÃ§Ã£o seja alimentar uma fogueira e que esse fogo seja roubado mais tarde - me lembrou Prometeu. Extremamente significativo Ã© descobrir quem Ã© o Senhor das Moscas, que obviamente nÃ£o vou contar aqui porque essa narrativa precisa ser lida. O Senhor Das Moscas Ã© um livro que a todo tempo nos faz pensar: o que nos torna bons ou maus? Somos frutos da sociedade? O que nos resta quando a civilidade Ã© tirada de nÃ³s?

Lord of the Flies is a 1954 novel by Nobel Prize-winning British author William Golding. The book focuses on a group of British boys stranded on an uninhabited island and their disastrous attempt to govern themselves.

El seÃ±or de las moscas es una novela de 1954 del autor britÃ¡nico ganador del Premio Nobel William Golding. El libro se centra en un grupo de niÃ±os britÃ¡nicos varados en una isla deshabitada y su desastroso intento de gobernarse a sÃ­ mismos. 
 
Es un verdadero clasico en donde vemos como la gente en esta ocasion niÃ±os, cambian de personalidades a vase de sus circunstacias para sobrevivir y las cosas que se atreven hacer. Muy triste y tragico pero a la vez maravilloso.
